III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12705 Release.
Section (1) An agency social service worker shall document that the
Description information has been provided for birth parents before
parents release their rights to their child unless the child
relinquished under chapter XII of the probate code of 1939,
1939 PA 288, MCL 712.1 to 712.20
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Adoption agency failed to confirm an alleged biological mother's
rights to her children.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Chief Administrator - On 11/3/2023, Chief Administrator was
interviewed by phone. She reported a woman claiming to be a
mother in Utah contacted the agency mid-July of 2023 and
indicated she was interested in releasing her rights to her three
children, who had been in her care since birth, and selecting a
Michigan family for their adoption. Agency staff gathered
preliminary information about the mother and children. The
agency staff asked the alleged birth mother for her identification
as well as the children’s birth certificates on 3-4 different
occasions. When she did not provide the documents, the agency
staff told her they could not move forward with any potential
adoption process until they had the documents. In September of
2023, the woman told the agency staff she would be leaving Utah
and moving to Michigan the following day and would call when
she arrived. The agency staff did not hear from the alleged birth
mother again, so they contacted the FBI and the Utah Division of
Child and Family Services. Within 6 hours, Utah Division of Child
and Family Services contacted the agency to tell them they were
able to identify the woman, and she was not who she claimed to
be. Additionally, the children she was alleging were hers are not
her children; rather, they are her relatives. Chief Administrator
reported the woman was never given any money, never asked for
any money, and was not at the point of releasing her rights to the
children when it was discovered that she was not telling them the
truth.
Child Advocate Specialist – On 11/14/2023, Child Advocate
Specialist was interviewed by phone. She stated she asked
Person 1 to provide her identification, but Person 1 reported she
had a social security card and the only other identification she had
was a fake ID. She told Child Advocate Specialist she would
provide her social security card once she arrived in Michigan.
Child Advocate Specialist reported she asked Person 1 for her
children’s birth certificates and other documents on several
occasions, but they were never provided. Child Advocate
Specialist stated her case contacts within the case record provide
an accurate reflection of the communication she had with Person
1.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
2

The following documents from the case record were reviewed:
• 7/15/2023 Initial online form regarding expressed interest in
agency services in which Person 1 identified her name,
birthday, and names and ages of her three children. She
indicated interest in talking with an adoption worker, talking
with an adoption attorney, and finding an adoptive family.
Case contacts:
• 7/17/2023 – Zoom meeting between Child Advocate
Specialist and Person 1 during which Person 1 reported
she was moving to Michigan from Utah on 8/4/2023 and
she was considering adoption for her three children. She
was informed the agency would need the children’s medical
records.
• 7/19/2023 – Release of information for the children’s
pediatrician was emailed to Person 1 by Child Advocate
Specialist, as well as a request for information regarding
the children’s daycare provider.
• 7/21/2023 – Phone call with Child Advocate Specialist
during which Person 1 stated she did not want to provide
the daycare information until it was closer to her leaving the
state because she works at the daycare. Child Advocate
Specialist asked for copies of the children’s birth
certificates. When Person 1 stated she didn’t think she had
them, Child Advocate Specialist informed her how to obtain
the documents from her county’s vital records department.
Child Advocate Specialist asked if the children’s daycare
provider had copies of the birth certificates. Person 1 stated
she thought they did and would ask for them.
• 7/25/2023 – Phone call with Child Advocate Specialist
during which Person 1 provided background information on
the children. She indicated she had three girls, 3-year-old
twins and a 1-year-old. She provided details about their
birth, personalities, medical history. She also provided
details about her upbringing as well as her work, education,
and health history. She stated there were no fathers named
on the birth certificates.
• 7/27/2023 – Child Advocate Specialist texted Person 1
asking her if pediatrician had signed the release of
information form.
• 7/28/2023 – Person 1 texted Child Advocate Specialist
stating the pediatrician would be sending the children’s
medical records to the agency.
3

• 7/31/2023 – Person 1 texted Child Advocate Specialist she
was planning to start her drive to Michigan 8/2/2023. Child
Advocate Specialist reminded her to bring the children’s
birth certificates and social security cards.
• 8/2/2023 – Phone call between Person 1 and Child
Advocate Specialist. Person 1 stated she did not leave for
Michigan.
• 8/11/2023 – Text exchanges between Child Advocate
Specialist and Person 1. Child Advocate Specialist again
provided information on how to obtain the children’s birth
certificates.
• 9/15/2023 – Child Advocate Specialist texted Person 1
requesting she send the children’s birth certificates and
social security cards.
• 9/17/2023 – Child Advocate Specialist texted Person 1
requesting the needed documents. Person 1 apologized
and stated she would send them from work the following
day.
• 9/18/2023 – Person 1 texted Child Advocate Specialist
apologizing for forgetting the paperwork and stated she
would send it the following day.
• 9/21/2023 – Person 1 called Child Advocate Specialist
stating she was not comfortable sending pictures or emails
of the children’s documents because she has a boss who
goes through her phone every evening and she doesn’t
want him to have that information. She is hoping to leave
Utah the following Friday.
• 9/22/2023 – Text exchange with Child Advocate Specialist
during which Person 1 stated plans to leave for Michigan
today and asked what documents she needed to bring.
Child Advocate Specialist reminded her of the needed
documents.
• 9/22/2023 - Multiple phone calls between Child Advocate
Specialist and Person 1 were abruptly ended. Person 1
stated her boss was sitting outside of her home. She
implied she was being trafficked and she believed her boss
knew of her plan to leave the state.
• 9/22/2023 – Child Advocate Specialist sent a text to Person
1 stating they could not move forward with adoption until
she turned 18 and she provided the children’s records in
hopes her boss would see the text and believe she was not
yet leaving the state.
4

• 9/23/2023 – Phone call between Child Advocate Specialist
and Person1 indicating once she can purchase a
Tracphone she will leave for Michigan. She stated she is
increasingly fearful for her children’s safety.
• 9/23/2023 – Chief Administrator phone call to FBI to report
concerns of Person 1 being trafficked.
• 9/24/2023 – Chief Administrator phone call to Utah Division
of Child and Family Services to report concerns of child
safety.
• 9/25/2023 – Phone call between Utah Division of Child and
Family Services and Child Advocate Specialist who was
informed Child Advocate Specialist Person 1 had been
located and she was not who she identified herself to be.
Additionally, the children she had been discussing with the
adoption agency were not her children.
Analysis A violation has not been established as Person 1 did not release
her rights to any children.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
